Moves: [{"Fen": "3r1b1k/ppq2Bpp/2p5/2P2Q2/8/1P4P1/P6P/5RK1 w - - 4 25", "Sign": null, "Number": 47, "Remark": "Initial Position", "Annotation": "Kh8"}, {"Fen": "3r1b1k/ppq2Bpp/2p5/2P2Q2/8/1P4P1/P6P/5RK1 w - - 4 25", "Sign": null, "Number": 48, "Remark": "Only legal move.", "Annotation": "Kh8"}, {"Fen": "3rBb1k/ppq3pp/2p5/2P2Q2/8/1P4P1/P6P/5RK1 b - - 5 25", "Sign": "!!", "Number": 49, "Remark": "The killer! A move so subtle but so devastating in the same time. It is breaking the connection between the rook and the bishop. Queen is incoming with great force and black's position is collapsing.", "Annotation": "Be8"}]
Description: At first glance black seems to be in trouble, white's queen and rook are looking powerful on the f file. But isn't queen in time to come and help out defending the f8 square? Not really, as white finds a beautiful move to break connection between black pieces and unleash a deadly attack.

Moves: [{"Fen": "5rk1/pp4pp/4p3/2R3Q1/3n4/2q4r/P1P2PPP/5RK1 b - - 1 23", "Sign": null, "Number": 44, "Remark": "Initial Position", "Annotation": "Rc5"}, {"Fen": "5rk1/pp4pp/4p3/2R3Q1/3n4/2q4r/P1P2PPP/5RK1 b - - 1 23", "Sign": null, "Number": 45, "Remark": "Decent try to defend this position.", "Annotation": "Rc5"}, {"Fen": "5rk1/pp4pp/4p3/2R3Q1/3n4/6qr/P1P2PPP/5RK1 w - - 2 24", "Sign": "!!", "Number": 46, "Remark": "A mind-blowing move! Queen can be taken three times but neither of them is good. White resigns.", "Annotation": "Qg3"}]
Description:
The rook on h3 cannot be taken because queen falls with Kf3+. Re4 seems to be more precise defense but white is still hopeless. 
After black plays Qg3!!: 
fxg3 does not work because of 24... Ne2+ 25. Kh1 Rxf1#
hxg3 does not work because: 24... Ne2#
Qxg3 does not work because: 24.Qxg3 Ne2+ 25.Kh1 Nxg3+ 26.fxg3 Rxf1#

Moves: [{"Fen": "r3n3/3b2kp/1qNp2p1/1p1Pp2n/1P2Pp2/3B1N1P/1Q3PP1/2R3K1 w - - 0 36", "Sign": null, "Number": 69, "Remark": "Initial Position", "Annotation": "Kxg7"}, {"Fen": "r3n3/3b2kp/1qNp2p1/1pRPp2n/1P2Pp2/3B1N1P/1Q3PP1/6K1 b - - 1 36", "Sign": null, "Number": 71, "Remark": "Not only is this the best move in the position it also creates a big psychological advantage. If dxc5 then Nfxe5 threating discovered check and taking the bishop on d7. Best continuation for black would be to block the check with Nhf3 where white regains material with Nxd7 and completely holds the center.", "Annotation": "Rc5"}, {"Fen": "r3n3/3b2kp/q1Np2p1/1pRPp2n/1P2Pp2/3B1N1P/1Q3PP1/6K1 w - - 2 37", "Sign": null, "Number": 72, "Remark": "Slightly better was Bxc6 to blunt the white's attack, but here the plan is to go Qa1+ and exchange the queens.", "Annotation": "Qa6"}, {"Fen": "r3n3/3b2kp/q1Np2p1/1R1Pp2n/1P2Pp2/3B1N1P/1Q3PP1/6K1 b - - 0 37", "Sign": null, "Number": 73, "Remark": "A free pawn.", "Annotation": "Rxb5"}, {"Fen": "r7/2nb2kp/q1Np2p1/1R1Pp2n/1P2Pp2/3B1N1P/1Q3PP1/6K1 w - - 1 38", "Sign": "?", "Number": 74, "Remark": "This is where the psychological advantage has effect: Bxc6 or Qa1+ were still the best choices to defend this position, but Hjartarson blunders.", "Annotation": "Nc7"}, {"Fen": "rR6/2nb2kp/q1Np2p1/3Pp2n/1P2Pp2/3B1N1P/1Q3PP1/6K1 b - - 2 38", "Sign": null, "Number": 75, "Remark": "With the discovered attack on the queen from the bishop on d3.", "Annotation": "Rb8"}, {"Fen": "rR6/2nb2kp/2Np2p1/3Pp2n/1P2Pp2/3q1N1P/1Q3PP1/6K1 w - - 0 39", "Sign": null, "Number": 76, "Remark": "There's not a lot of other options (maybe still going for Qa1+ is the best try)", "Annotation": "Qxd3"}, {"Fen": "rR6/2nb2kp/3p2p1/3PN2n/1P2Pp2/3q1N1P/1Q3PP1/6K1 b - - 0 39", "Sign": "!", "Number": 77, "Remark": "A perfect ending to this combo! Leaving his rook to hang, Tal attacks opponent's queen and lasers the opponent's king with his queen on b2. The attack is overwhelming.", "Annotation": "Ncxe5"}]
Description: One of many gems from the eight World Chess Champion. His ability to find moves like these were what made him a true legend of chess. At the end of the combo black can give a check Qd1+ but white's king is safe on h2 and the queen will soon be unleashed on the diagonal!

Moves: [{"Fen": "r3r1k1/1p1b1pp1/1p5p/3Pq3/7R/P2Q1B2/1P4PP/R6K w - - 3 24", "Sign": null, "Number": 45, "Remark": "Initial Position", "Annotation": "Qe5"}, {"Fen": "r3r1k1/1p1b1pp1/1p5p/3Pq3/1R6/P2Q1B2/1P4PP/R6K b - - 4 24", "Sign": null, "Number": 47, "Remark": "Miscalculation. Trying to defend the pawn on b2 when the back rank is more vulnerable. Defending it while taking care of the back rank issue with Rd4 or Qg4 was the better choice.", "Annotation": "Rb4"}, {"Fen": "4r1k1/1p1b1pp1/1p5p/3Pq3/1R6/r2Q1B2/1P4PP/R6K w - - 0 25", "Sign": "!!", "Number": 48, "Remark": "Bronstein strikes mercilessly! Taking back with the rook doesn't work because Qe1+ with incoming mate. Taking back with the pawn ends with 25... Qxa1+ 26. Rb1 Re1+ with mate in next few moves.", "Annotation": "Rxa3"}]
Description: No wonder GM Bronstein was considered master of tactics. His opponent makes a mistake with Rb4 and he immediately strikes with a beautiful move Rxa3. After this brilliancy white had the option of allowing mate or giving up his queen so the only move that made sense was to resign!

Moves:
[{"Fen": "1Q2R3/6pk/7p/8/6P1/1p3q2/1P1r2PK/8 w - - 0 38", "Sign": null, "Number": 73, "Remark": "Initial Position", "Annotation": "Qxf3"}, {"Fen": "1Q5R/6pk/7p/8/6P1/1p3q2/1P1r2PK/8 b - - 1 38", "Sign": null, "Number": 75, "Remark": "The fatal attack starts!", "Annotation": "Rh8+"}, {"Fen": "1Q5R/6p1/6kp/8/6P1/1p3q2/1P1r2PK/8 w - - 2 39", "Sign": null, "Number": 76, "Remark": "Only move.", "Annotation": "Kg6"}, {"Fen": "1Q6/6p1/6kR/8/6P1/1p3q2/1P1r2PK/8 b - - 0 39", "Sign": "!!", "Number": 77, "Remark": "The killer! White sacrifices his rook for a moment but black queen falls in all continuations. 
If black recaptures with the pawn then: 40. Qg8+ Kf6 41. Qf8+ Ke5 42. Qxf3
If he recaptures with the king then: 40.Qh8+ Kg6 41.Qh5+ Kf6 42.g5+ Ke6 43. Qxf3
And if he tries to run away: 39... Kf7 40. Qc7+ Kg8 41. Qc8+ Qf8 42. Rh8+ Kxh8 43. Qxf8+", "Annotation": "Rxh6+"}]
Description: At initial glance both kings look equally (un)safe behind couple of pawns. White is one pawn up, but has doubled pawns. Is this a draw? Not if you ask a tactical genius like David Bronstein! Black slips up by grabbing the pawn on f3 and it is more than enough for Bronstein to take the win.

Moves: [{"Fen": "rnb1kb1r/pp3ppp/2p2n2/4q3/4N3/3Q4/PPPB1PPP/2KR1BNR b kq - 1 8", "Sign": null, "Number": 14, "Remark": "Initial Position", "Annotation": "O-O-O"}, {"Fen": "rnb1kb1r/pp3ppp/2p2n2/4q3/4N3/3Q4/PPPB1PPP/2KR1BNR b kq - 1 8", "Sign": null, "Number": 15, "Remark": "Is white giving up his knight on e4?", "Annotation": "O-O-O"}, {"Fen": "rnb1kb1r/pp3ppp/2p5/4q3/4n3/3Q4/PPPB1PPP/2KR1BNR w kq - 0 9", "Sign": "??", "Number": 16, "Remark": "Not really. The opening trap has succeeded!", "Annotation": "Nxe4"}, {"Fen": "rnbQkb1r/pp3ppp/2p5/4q3/4n3/8/PPPB1PPP/2KR1BNR b kq - 1 9", "Sign": null, "Number": 17, "Remark": "The d file is to vulnerable with the rook and queen eying black king.", "Annotation": "Qd8+"}, {"Fen": "rnbk1b1r/pp3ppp/2p5/4q3/4n3/8/PPPB1PPP/2KR1BNR w - - 0 10", "Sign": null, "Number": 18, "Remark": "Only move.", "Annotation": "Kxd8"}, {"Fen": "rnbk1b1r/pp3ppp/2p5/4q1B1/4n3/8/PPP2PPP/2KR1BNR b - - 1 10", "Sign": null, "Number": 19, "Remark": "Double check from the rook and from the bishop.", "Annotation": "Bg5+"}, {"Fen": "rnb2b1r/ppk2ppp/2p5/4q1B1/4n3/8/PPP2PPP/2KR1BNR w - - 2 11", "Sign": null, "Number": 20, "Remark": "Equally bad alternative was Ke8 with rook coming to d8 to deliver the checkmate.", "Annotation": "Kc7"}, {"Fen": "rnbB1b1r/ppk2ppp/2p5/4q3/4n3/8/PPP2PPP/2KR1BNR b - - 3 11", "Sign": null, "Number": 21, "Remark": "Bishop and the rook combine for mate to end this beautiful opening trap!", "Annotation": "Bd8#"}]
Description: Who wouldn't fall for that seemingly free knight? Tartakower famously said "The blunders are all there on the board, waiting to be made." and he sure found one early in this game.

Moves: [{"Fen": "r1b2r1k/4qp1p/p2ppb1Q/4nP2/1p1NP3/2N5/PPP4P/2KR1BR1 w - - 4 18", "Sign": null, "Number": 33, "Remark": "Initial Position", "Annotation": "Qe7"}, {"Fen": "r1b2r1k/4qp1p/p1Nppb1Q/4nP2/1p2P3/2N5/PPP4P/2KR1BR1 b - - 5 18", "Sign": "!!", "Number": 35, "Remark": "Astonishing move! Stockfish sees it only on bigger depth. White is sacrificing a knight in order to make the king's defense even weaker.", "Annotation": "Nc6"}, {"Fen": "r1b2r1k/4qp1p/p1nppb1Q/5P2/1p2P3/2N5/PPP4P/2KR1BR1 w - - 0 19", "Sign": null, "Number": 36, "Remark": "Only logical answer to this move.", "Annotation": "Nxc6"}, {"Fen": "r1b2r1k/4qp1p/p1nppb1Q/4PP2/1p6/2N5/PPP4P/2KR1BR1 b - - 0 19", "Sign": "!", "Number": 37, "Remark": "Giving the knight an good square on e4 or removing another defender of the king.", "Annotation": "e5"}, {"Fen": "r1b2r1k/4qp1p/p1npp2Q/4PPb1/1p6/2N5/PPP4P/2KR1BR1 w - - 1 20", "Sign": null, "Number": 38, "Remark": "Black decides to give a piece back in order to blunt white's attack. Not the most precise move, but this happens often when a brilliancy is played!", "Annotation": "Bg5+"}, {"Fen": "r1b2r1k/4qp1p/p1npp2Q/4PPR1/1p6/2N5/PPP4P/2KR1B2 b - - 0 20", "Sign": null, "Number": 39, "Remark": "Getting back the sacrificed material while having a much better attack. White ends up in a dream scenario.", "Annotation": "Rxg5"}]
Description: It takes a real brilliancy to outplay a former world champion this way. With black close to consolidating and a knight being under attack on c3, Kholmov finds a way to make things complicated and to take the initiative. At first glance it is a senseless move, but it actually enables the white's attack.

Moves: [{"Fen": "3r2k1/p4ppp/1q6/8/8/2r1P3/P3QPPP/2R3K1 w - - 0 29", "Sign": null, "Number": 55, "Remark": "Initial Position", "Annotation": "Rxc3"}, {"Fen": "3r2k1/p4ppp/1q6/8/8/2R1P3/P3QPPP/6K1 b - - 0 29", "Sign": "?", "Number": 57, "Remark": "Rd1+ is covered by the queen. Check on b1 is blocked by queen to f1, so white is safe, right?", "Annotation": "Rxc3"}, {"Fen": "3r2k1/p4ppp/8/8/8/2R1P3/Pq2QPPP/6K1 w - - 1 30", "Sign": "!", "Number": 58, "Remark": "Wrong! Capablanca shows why he became a world champion. White can either take the queen and allow mate with Rd1# or he can defend with Qf1 and sacrifice his rook. Resigns.", "Annotation": "Qb2"}]
Description: In what can look as an equal position to untrained eye, a future Chess World Champion finds a moment of brilliance. Using the threat of back rank mate he forces white player to give up his rook. Such a simple, but a deadly move.

Moves: [{"Fen": "8/7p/5kp1/4p3/p3rPRP/2K3P1/8/8 w - - 0 43", "Sign": null, "Number": 83, "Remark": "Initial Position", "Annotation": "Rxe4"}, {"Fen": "8/7p/5kp1/4p3/p3rPRP/3K2P1/8/8 b - - 1 43", "Sign": null, "Number": 85, "Remark": "Black threatens to take the rook on e4.", "Annotation": "Kd3"}, {"Fen": "8/6kp/6p1/4p3/p3rPRP/3K2P1/8/8 w - - 2 44", "Sign": "!!", "Number": 86, "Remark": "The silent killer! This is the most precise move in the combination, moving away from check fxe5+.", "Annotation": "Kg7"}, {"Fen": "8/6kp/6p1/4p2P/p3rPR1/3K2P1/8/8 b - - 0 44", "Sign": null, "Number": 87, "Remark": "White realizes that taking the rook will result in queening of the a pawn.", "Annotation": "h5"}, {"Fen": "8/6kp/6p1/4p2P/4rPR1/p2K2P1/8/8 w - - 0 45", "Sign": null, "Number": 88, "Remark": "But there's no stopping of this pawn nevertheless.", "Annotation": "a3"}, {"Fen": "8/6kp/6p1/4p2P/4KPR1/p5P1/8/8 b - - 0 45", "Sign": null, "Number": 89, "Remark": "White's last hope is to build a fortress.", "Annotation": "Kxe4"}, {"Fen": "8/6kp/6p1/4p2P/4KPR1/6P1/p7/8 w - - 0 46", "Sign": null, "Number": 90, "Remark": "The march continues.", "Annotation": "a2"}, {"Fen": "8/6kp/6P1/4p3/4KPR1/6P1/p7/8 b - - 0 46", "Sign": null, "Number": 91, "Remark": "Exchanging material in hope of a draw.", "Annotation": "hxg6"}, {"Fen": "8/6k1/6p1/4p3/4KPR1/6P1/p7/8 w - - 0 47", "Sign": null, "Number": 92, "Remark": "Black is in no rush.", "Annotation": "hxg6"}, {"Fen": "8/6k1/6p1/4p1R1/4KP2/6P1/p7/8 b - - 1 47", "Sign": null, "Number": 93, "Remark": "Freeing the rook.", "Annotation": "Rg5"}, {"Fen": "8/6k1/6p1/4p1R1/4KP2/6P1/8/q7 w - - 0 48", "Sign": null, "Number": 94, "Remark": "The a pawn has finally finished the journey. White will take the pawn on e5 but a Queen is to o overwhelming in this endgame.", "Annotation": "a1=Q"}]
Description: Some moves are notable for how subtle they are. This combo highlights one of those. It's not always about material and sometimes you need to make one step back in order to make greater progress. That idea is pictured perfectly in Geller's Kg7.

Moves: [{"Fen": "8/5B2/6Kp/6pP/5b2/p7/1k3P2/8 b - - 3 69", "Sign": null, "Number": 136, "Remark": "Initial Position", "Annotation": "Kg6"}, {"Fen": "8/5B2/6Kp/6pP/8/p3b3/1k3P2/8 w - - 4 70", "Sign": "!!", "Number": 138, "Remark": "Only winning move! Black wants to clear the line for the g pawn by all means. The bishop on f7 is in time to stop the a2 pawn but another passed pawn would be too much.", "Annotation": "Be3"}, {"Fen": "8/5B2/7K/6pP/8/p3b3/1k3P2/8 b - - 0 70", "Sign": null, "Number": 139, "Remark": "Grabbing a pawn as white can't really do anything about the double passed pawns.", "Annotation": "Kxh6"}, {"Fen": "8/5B2/7K/7P/6p1/p3b3/1k3P2/8 w - - 0 71", "Sign": null, "Number": 140, "Remark": "Getting closer to queening with check.", "Annotation": "g4+"}, {"Fen": "8/5B2/7K/7P/6p1/p3P3/1k6/8 b - - 0 71", "Sign": null, "Number": 141, "Remark": "Moving away with Kg7 or Kg6 would result in similar ending.", "Annotation": "fxe3"}, {"Fen": "8/5B2/7K/7P/8/p3P1p1/1k6/8 w - - 0 72", "Sign": null, "Number": 142, "Remark": "Black has two pawns two fields from queening and white has only one bishop to catch them! The position is overwhelming for white.", "Annotation": "g3"}]
Description: In an endgame position like this putting your bishop to be taken with a pawn seems like a ludicrous idea! But this is exactly what black does and it's by far the best move in the position. Two "passers" simply offer more value than a bishop does in this position and it takes a true master to see this.

Moves: [{"Fen": "3r2k1/R4bpp/1p3pn1/3N2q1/3P4/P4QP1/BP3P2/6K1 b - - 0 33", "Sign": null, "Number": 64, "Remark": "Initial Position", "Annotation": "Nxd5"}, {"Fen": "3r2k1/R5pp/1p3pn1/3b2q1/3P4/P4QP1/BP3P2/6K1 w - - 0 34", "Sign": null, "Number": 66, "Remark": "The knight falls with Bxd5 and that bishop looks very powerful in the center of the board - eying both the queen on f3 and white's bishop on a2. What to do?", "Annotation": "Bxd5"}, {"Fen": "R2r2k1/6pp/1p3pn1/3b2q1/3P4/P4QP1/BP3P2/6K1 b - - 1 34", "Sign": "!!", "Number": 67, "Remark": "Glorious! Seemingly white offers another piece to black but if Rxa8 then 35. Bxd5+ Kh8 36. Bxa8 and white is now in a completely winning endgame. Note that black can't do anything with the bishop because of the pin.", "Annotation": "Ra8"}, {"Fen": "R2r2k1/6pp/1p3pn1/6q1/3P4/P4QP1/bP3P2/6K1 w - - 0 35", "Sign": null, "Number": 68, "Remark": "Taking the rook with Rxa8 may be more precise (or even check with Qc1+) but white is developing a strong attack in any case.", "Annotation": "Bxa2"}, {"Fen": "3R2k1/6pp/1p3pn1/6q1/3P4/P4QP1/bP3P2/6K1 b - - 0 35", "Sign": null, "Number": 69, "Remark": "Taking the rook with check and although there's still work to do white's queen will join the attack soon and harass the black king.", "Annotation": "Rxd8+"}]
Description: Such an unusual position where it seems that the black's bishop is extremely powerful in the center but is being dominated by the bishop on a2 in reality. Tal utilizes his amazing attacking talent to transform the position and do what Tal does best: sacrifice some material for an unstoppable attack!

Moves: [{"Fen": "2r2rk1/pp3pp1/4bb1p/q2p3Q/3P1P2/2N5/PP4PP/1K1R1B1R w - - 1 17", "Sign": null, "Number": 31, "Remark": "Initial Position", "Annotation": "Rac8"}, {"Fen": "2r2rk1/pp3pp1/4bb1p/q2p1P1Q/3P4/2N5/PP4PP/1K1R1B1R b - - 0 17", "Sign": null, "Number": 33, "Remark": "Attacking the bishop on f6.", "Annotation": "f5"}, {"Fen": "5rk1/pp3pp1/4bb1p/q2p1P1Q/3P4/2r5/PP4PP/1K1R1B1R w - - 0 18", "Sign": "!", "Number": 34, "Remark": "Black doesn't care about the bishop. White's king is all alone and he's soon going to be under heavy fire.", "Annotation": "Rxc3"}, {"Fen": "5rk1/pp3pp1/4Pb1p/q2p3Q/3P4/2r5/PP4PP/1K1R1B1R b - - 0 18", "Sign": null, "Number": 35, "Remark": "Black can't make his king even weaker with bxc3, he chooses the best option.", "Annotation": "fxe6"}, {"Fen": "5rk1/pp3pp1/4Pb1p/q2p3Q/3P4/r7/PP4PP/1K1R1B1R w - - 1 19", "Sign": "!!", "Number": 36, "Remark": "Only move that keeps the winning advantage! White will have to take it but the combination of the queen and rook (which will join the attack on the c file) is too dangerous for white. What a combination from the then World Chess Champion!", "Annotation": "Ra3"}]
Description: Playing style of the World Chess Champion with the longest reign in history was so ahead of its time that some of his contemporaries thought he was just a  "coffee-house player". This combo shows exactly why they thought that but it also shows how wrong they were. Playing such precise moves and sacrificing material for positional advantage is exactly what made him the World Chess Champion for 27 years.

Moves: [{"Fen": "1r4nk/1p1qb2p/3p1r2/p1pPp3/2P1Pp2/5P1P/PP1QNBRK/5R2 b - - 3 30", "Sign": null, "Number": 58, "Remark": "Initial Position", "Annotation": "Ne2"}, {"Fen": "1r4nk/1p2b2p/3p1r2/p1pPp3/2P1Pp2/5P1q/PP1QNBRK/5R2 w - - 0 31", "Sign": "!!", "Number": 60, "Remark": "A stroke of genius! Black recognizes that white's queen is blocked and king is completely exposed. Running away with Kg1 is playable but white would move his rook to the h file and soon win even more material.", "Annotation": "Qxh3+"}, {"Fen": "1r4nk/1p2b2p/3p1r2/p1pPp3/2P1Pp2/5P1K/PP1QNBR1/5R2 b - - 0 31", "Sign": null, "Number": 61, "Remark": "Only sensible thing to try.", "Annotation": "Kxh3"}, {"Fen": "1r4nk/1p2b2p/3p3r/p1pPp3/2P1Pp2/5P1K/PP1QNBR1/5R2 w - - 1 32", "Sign": null, "Number": 62, "Remark": "Of course! Black's pieces are all just waiting to join the attack.", "Annotation": "Rh6+"}, {"Fen": "1r4nk/1p2b2p/3p3r/p1pPp3/2P1PpK1/5P2/PP1QNBR1/5R2 b - - 2 32", "Sign": null, "Number": 63, "Remark": "Only legal move.", "Annotation": "Kg4"}, {"Fen": "1r5k/1p2b2p/3p1n1r/p1pPp3/2P1PpK1/5P2/PP1QNBR1/5R2 w - - 3 33", "Sign": null, "Number": 64, "Remark": "Not only is the knight joining the party with check but also clearing the way for the rook on g file.", "Annotation": "Nf6+"}, {"Fen": "1r5k/1p2b2p/3p1n1r/p1pPpK2/2P1Pp2/5P2/PP1QNBR1/5R2 b - - 4 33", "Sign": null, "Number": 65, "Remark": "Again, only move that doesn't loose on the spot. ( 33.Kg5 Rh5# )", "Annotation": "Kf5"}, {"Fen": "1r5k/1p1nb2p/3p3r/p1pPpK2/2P1Pp2/5P2/PP1QNBR1/5R2 w - - 5 34", "Sign": null, "Number": 66, "Remark": "Clearing the way for the rook on f file but also for his bishop on e7.", "Annotation": "Nd7"}, {"Fen": "1r5k/1p1nb2p/3p3r/p1pPpKR1/2P1Pp2/5P2/PP1QNB2/5R2 b - - 6 34", "Sign": null, "Number": 67, "Remark": "White starts giving back material to preserve any hope of surviving.", "Annotation": "Rg5"}, {"Fen": "5r1k/1p1nb2p/3p3r/p1pPpKR1/2P1Pp2/5P2/PP1QNB2/5R2 w - - 7 35", "Sign": null, "Number": 68, "Remark": "Look at this position! Black may be a piece down but all of his remaining pieces are attacking the king mercilessly. The situation is overwhelming for black.", "Annotation": "Rf8+"}]
Description: It's every chess player's dream to sacrifice his queen for a brutal attack. Only a true master can pull it off and rarely it is done better than in this combo from Soviet grandmaster Alexander Kotov. Recognizing that it is hard for white to coordinate his pieces he sacrifices his queen and develops a deadly attack.

Moves: [{"Fen": "r3r1k1/1pq2pp1/2p2n2/1PNn4/2QN2b1/6P1/3RPP2/2R3KB b - - 0 26", "Sign": null, "Number": 50, "Remark": "Initial Position", "Annotation": "axb5"}, {"Fen": "r5k1/1pq2pp1/2p2n2/1PNn4/2QN2b1/4r1P1/3RPP2/2R3KB w - - 1 27", "Sign": null, "Number": 52, "Remark": "Such an aesthetically pleasing move! White can't take because queen comes in with Qg3+.", "Annotation": "Re3"}, {"Fen": "r5k1/1pq2pp1/2p2n2/1PNn4/2Q3b1/4rNP1/3RPP2/2R3KB b - - 2 27", "Sign": "?", "Number": 53, "Remark": "Objectively Re3 wasn't so devastating, but it had a great psychological effect on the opponent. He blunders this move and remove his knight from a beautiful square on d4", "Annotation": "Nf3"}, {"Fen": "r5k1/1pq2pp1/5n2/1pNn4/2Q3b1/4rNP1/3RPP2/2R3KB w - - 0 28", "Sign": null, "Number": 54, "Remark": "Removing the queen as a defender of c3.", "Annotation": "cxb5"}, {"Fen": "r5k1/1pq2pp1/5n2/1QNn4/6b1/4rNP1/3RPP2/2R3KB b - - 0 28", "Sign": null, "Number": 55, "Remark": "It was probably better to leave the pawn with Qd4. Defending the c3 field is of great importance.", "Annotation": "Qxb5"}, {"Fen": "r5k1/1pq2pp1/5n2/1QN5/6b1/2n1rNP1/3RPP2/2R3KB w - - 1 29", "Sign": null, "Number": 56, "Remark": "The knight will soon join the attack on the king with Nxe2+ and the other knight will jump to e4. With 4 pieces in close proximity to the king no wonder black went home with a victory.", "Annotation": "Nc3"}]
Description: In what was a truly beautiful and wild game we've chosen this sequence as the most beautiful one. It's hard to fit the whole game in a single combo! In what is a equal position black manages to destabilize everything with a beautiful rook infiltration and expose the weaknesses of the white king. A truly memorable game!

Moves: [{"Fen": "r4rk1/pp5p/4b3/q2pp3/3PN3/PQ5p/1P3PP1/2R3K1 w - - 0 23", "Sign": null, "Number": 43, "Remark": "Initial Position", "Annotation": "fxe5"}, {"Fen": "r4rk1/pp5p/4b3/q2pp3/3PN3/P5Qp/1P3PP1/2R3K1 b - - 1 23", "Sign": null, "Number": 45, "Remark": "Completely logical move. If black moves to Kh8 white moves in with devastating Qxe5+. If he moves to Kf7 then the knight jumps in with check Nd6+ and white is soon winning material. What to do?", "Annotation": "Qg3+"}, {"Fen": "r4rk1/pp5p/8/q2pp3/3PN1b1/P5Qp/1P3PP1/2R3K1 w - - 2 24", "Sign": "!!", "Number": 46, "Remark": "There's great defensive moves and there's this! Moving the queen from the h2-b8 diagonal is just enough time for black to save himself as the threat of Qxe5 is no longer there.", "Annotation": "Bg4"}, {"Fen": "r4rk1/pp5p/8/q2pp3/3PN1Q1/P6p/1P3PP1/2R3K1 b - - 0 24", "Sign": null, "Number": 47, "Remark": "White is down in material so he decides to take a piece back.", "Annotation": "Qxg4+"}, {"Fen": "r4r1k/pp5p/8/q2pp3/3PN1Q1/P6p/1P3PP1/2R3K1 w - - 1 25", "Sign": null, "Number": 48, "Remark": "Hiding the king from danger. White has seemingly a good attack going but it is too slow as he has to deal with the weak f pawn and black's incoming h pawn.", "Annotation": "Kh8"}]
Description: A piece sacrifice to hold the attack? Not something you see everyday, especially done this good. Famous Danish grandmaster Bent Larsen finds only defensive move that holds his position and after hiding his king on h8 he's the one who's always a move closer to mating his opponent. In the game he actually went for the pragmatic route - exchanging queens and converting his material advantage.

Moves: [{"Fen": "1rq5/2kB3Q/3p1r2/3P1Pp1/1R2p3/p1P1P2P/P5P1/6K1 b - - 0 42", "Sign": null, "Number": 82, "Remark": "Initial Position", "Annotation": "Bxd7"}, {"Fen": "1r4q1/2kB3Q/3p1r2/3P1Pp1/1R2p3/p1P1P2P/P5P1/6K1 w - - 1 43", "Sign": null, "Number": 84, "Remark": "Black realizes he is in trouble and tries to exchange the queens.", "Annotation": "Qg8"}, {"Fen": "1r4q1/1RkB3Q/3p1r2/3P1Pp1/4p3/p1P1P2P/P5P1/6K1 b - - 2 43", "Sign": "!", "Number": 85, "Remark": "But he enables this brilliant move! Giving up his rook in a beautiful combo that would see him win black's queen.", "Annotation": "Rb7+"}, {"Fen": "1r4q1/1k1B3Q/3p1r2/3P1Pp1/4p3/p1P1P2P/P5P1/6K1 w - - 0 44", "Sign": null, "Number": 86, "Remark": "Take what you can.", "Annotation": "Kxb7"}, {"Fen": "1rB3q1/1k5Q/3p1r2/3P1Pp1/4p3/p1P1P2P/P5P1/6K1 b - - 1 44", "Sign": "!", "Number": 87, "Remark": "Double check and the whole point of the combo. Black can't just take the bishop because then even his rook will fall. For example 44. ...Kxc8 45.Qxg8+ Kc7 46.Qg7+ Kc8 47.Qxf6 and white is completely winning.", "Annotation": "Bc8+"}]
Description: Even though white is down an exchange there's not much breathing room for black's king. White capitalizes on this weakness in great fashion by temporarily sacrificing his rook and utilizing the discovered attack in the best way possible. One of those combinations that seem obvious when you see it but it takes a great tactical awareness to spot them over the board.

Moves: [{"Fen": "r1br4/1p2npkp/3Bpbp1/pqp5/2N1R3/1P1P1QP1/1PP2PBP/R5K1 w - - 6 19", "Sign": null, "Number": 35, "Remark": "Initial Position", "Annotation": "Rd8"}, {"Fen": "r1br4/1p2npkp/3BpQp1/pqp5/2N1R3/1P1P2P1/1PP2PBP/R5K1 b - - 0 19", "Sign": "!!", "Number": 37, "Remark": "Petrosian spots a mate in 7! A beautiful queen sacrifice that completely exposes black king.", "Annotation": "Qxf6+"}, {"Fen": "r1br4/1p2np1p/3Bpkp1/pqp5/2N1R3/1P1P2P1/1PP2PBP/R5K1 w - - 0 20", "Sign": null, "Number": 38, "Remark": "Only thing you can try or you are two pieces down.", "Annotation": "Kxf6"}, {"Fen": "r1br4/1p2np1p/4pkp1/pqp1B3/2N1R3/1P1P2P1/1PP2PBP/R5K1 b - - 1 20", "Sign": null, "Number": 39, "Remark": "The reason why the combo works. Black king must continue his walk to the center of the board.", "Annotation": "Be5+"}, {"Fen": "r1br4/1p2np1p/4p1p1/pqp1B1k1/2N1R3/1P1P2P1/1PP2PBP/R5K1 w - - 2 21", "Sign": null, "Number": 40, "Remark": "Not much difference between this or Kf5.", "Annotation": "Kg5"}, {"Fen": "r1br4/1p2npBp/4p1p1/pqp3k1/2N1R3/1P1P2P1/1PP2PBP/R5K1 b - - 3 21", "Sign": null, "Number": 41, "Remark": "A really nice finish to the combo! White's bishop is doing a great job of keeping the black king high up the board.", "Annotation": "Bg7"}]
Description: Known for his defensive style, Petrosian notices and deploys a beautiful attack in this game. He recognizes that there's not enough defensive pieces around black's king and doesn't hesitate to give material in order to setup a deadly attack. White doesn't just give a little bit of material though, a full queen for a bishop! But the beautiful calculation is spot on, as it usually is the case with Petrosian, and leads to a quick check mate.

Moves: [{"Fen": "4q3/p5kp/1p2Pnp1/3pQ3/2pP4/1nP3N1/1B4PP/6K1 b - - 4 29", "Sign": null, "Number": 56, "Remark": "Initial Position", "Annotation": "Qe5"}, {"Fen": "8/p3q1kp/1p2Pnp1/3pQ3/2pP4/1nP3N1/1B4PP/6K1 w - - 5 30", "Sign": null, "Number": 58, "Remark": "Black is trying to stop the passed pawn.", "Annotation": "Qe7"}, {"Fen": "8/p3q1kp/1p2Pnp1/3pQ3/2pP4/BnP3N1/6PP/6K1 b - - 6 30", "Sign": "!", "Number": 59, "Remark": "A great sacrifice in order to distract the queen from defense of the king and from blocking the e pawn.", "Annotation": "Ba3"}, {"Fen": "8/p5kp/1p2Pnp1/3pQ3/2pP4/qnP3N1/6PP/6K1 w - - 0 31", "Sign": null, "Number": 60, "Remark": "Moving back to e8 is also a move but makes the position even harder for black as his queen becomes more passive and the knight on b3 is completely out of the action.", "Annotation": "Qxa3"}, {"Fen": "8/p5kp/1p2Pnp1/3pQ2N/2pP4/qnP5/6PP/6K1 b - - 1 31", "Sign": "!", "Number": 61, "Remark": "Like sacrificing the bishop is not enough, white gives away his last remaining piece!", "Annotation": "Nh5+"}, {"Fen": "8/p5kp/1p2Pn2/3pQ2p/2pP4/qnP5/6PP/6K1 w - - 0 32", "Sign": null, "Number": 62, "Remark": "Moving away to h6 is shown as more precise by Stockfish but giving away the last defender of the king makes sense only if you are interested in losing slower.", "Annotation": "gxh5"}, {"Fen": "8/p5kp/1p2Pn2/3p2Qp/2pP4/qnP5/6PP/6K1 b - - 1 32", "Sign": null, "Number": 63, "Remark": "Time to get one of the pieces back.", "Annotation": "Qg5+"}, {"Fen": "5k2/p6p/1p2Pn2/3p2Qp/2pP4/qnP5/6PP/6K1 w - - 2 33", "Sign": null, "Number": 64, "Remark": "Ka8 is almost completely the same.", "Annotation": "Kf8"}, {"Fen": "5k2/p6p/1p2PQ2/3p3p/2pP4/qnP5/6PP/6K1 b - - 0 33", "Sign": null, "Number": 65, "Remark": "The end is now in sight, combination of the queen and pawn is too strong for the lonely king. Black does have some checks but as soon as white hides the king it is game over.", "Annotation": "Qxf6+"}]
Description: With position looking just about equal white shows how to take the only advantage you have and turn it into a game-winning difference. In this position that advanced e pawn is exactly that advantage which allows Botvinnik to find a beautiful combo which sacrifices some material to make the e pawn an unstoppable force on the board.

Moves: [{"Fen": "1rb2rk1/p1p3pp/2pb4/3p4/3Pp3/4B2q/PPPQBP1P/2KR3R b - - 3 17", "Sign": null, "Number": 32, "Remark": "Initial Position", "Annotation": "O-O-O"}, {"Fen": "1rb3k1/p1p3pp/2pb4/3p4/3Pp3/4B2q/PPPQBr1P/2KR3R w - - 0 18", "Sign": "!!", "Number": 34, "Remark": "Amazing rook sacrifice! Morphy was a player completely ahead of his time and this move shows why. Even Stockfish needs some time to recognize how good this move actually is.", "Annotation": "Rxf2"}, {"Fen": "1rb3k1/p1p3pp/2pb4/3p4/3Pp3/7q/PPPQBB1P/2KR3R b - - 0 18", "Sign": null, "Number": 35, "Remark": "White decides to take all that extra material which actually is the most precise move in the position.", "Annotation": "Bxf2"}, {"Fen": "1rb3k1/p1p3pp/2pb4/3p4/3Pp3/q7/PPPQBB1P/2KR3R w - - 1 19", "Sign": "!", "Number": 36, "Remark": "The beauty never stops when Paul Morphy is playing. Simply bxa3 after this queen move runs into mate with Bxa3 so playing a defensive move like c3 is the only defense. Now the a pawn is falling and king is suddenly looking really weak. Absolutely glorious attack from black.", "Annotation": "Qa3"}]
Description: Morphy's career was short but full of beautiful combos. He's probably one of rare players where we can select multiple combos from a single game he played and this is one of those games. In just two moves he sacrifices his rook and offers his queen to be taken. What more can you ask? Well, there's more to come as he also sacrifices his bishop to completely destroy the pawn wall in front of the king but that's probably material for another combo.

Moves: [{"Fen": "2rr2k1/1b3ppp/pb2p3/1p2P3/1P2BPnq/P1N5/1B2Q1PP/R4R1K w - - 5 22", "Sign": null, "Number": 41, "Remark": "Initial Position", "Annotation": "Qh4"}, {"Fen": "2rr2k1/1b3ppp/pb2p3/1p2P3/1P2BPnq/P1N3P1/1B2Q2P/R4R1K b - - 0 22", "Sign": null, "Number": 43, "Remark": "A natural looking move, white wants to kick the queen away.", "Annotation": "g3"}, {"Fen": "3r2k1/1b3ppp/pb2p3/1p2P3/1P2BPnq/P1r3P1/1B2Q2P/R4R1K w - - 0 23", "Sign": "!!", "Number": 44, "Remark": "Black has other plans, leaving his queen to hang and making an exchange sacrifice.", "Annotation": "Rxc3"}, {"Fen": "3r2k1/1b3ppp/pb2p3/1p2P3/1P2BPnP/P1r5/1B2Q2P/R4R1K b - - 0 23", "Sign": null, "Number": 45, "Remark": "There's not much black can do now.", "Annotation": "gxh4"}, {"Fen": "6k1/1b3ppp/pb2p3/1p2P3/1P2BPnP/P1r5/1B1rQ2P/R4R1K w - - 1 24", "Sign": "!!", "Number": 46, "Remark": "As if a queen is not enough, black sacrifices a rook too. The idea is to remove the defender of the white bishop and produce an unstoppable attack.", "Annotation": "Rd2"}, {"Fen": "6k1/1b3ppp/pb2p3/1p2P3/1P2BPnP/P1r5/1B1Q3P/R4R1K b - - 0 24", "Sign": null, "Number": 47, "Remark": "Nothing else really makes much sense.", "Annotation": "Qxd2"}, {"Fen": "6k1/5ppp/pb2p3/1p2P3/1P2bPnP/P1r5/1B1Q3P/R4R1K w - - 0 25", "Sign": null, "Number": 48, "Remark": "This bishop now comes in with a check and great thunder!", "Annotation": "Bxe4+"}, {"Fen": "6k1/5ppp/pb2p3/1p2P3/1P2bPnP/P1r5/1B4QP/R4R1K b - - 1 25", "Sign": null, "Number": 49, "Remark": "Only move.", "Annotation": "Qg2"}, {"Fen": "6k1/5ppp/pb2p3/1p2P3/1P2bPnP/P6r/1B4QP/R4R1K w - - 2 26", "Sign": "!", "Number": 50, "Remark": "White is completely locked. Queen can't move and there's nothing to do about the incoming Rxh2.", "Annotation": "Rh3"}]
Description: Your queen is attacked by a pawn, but your pair of bishops is looking extremely menacing. What do you do? Well of course, sacrifice the queen and produce one more memorable moment in the history of chess.
